fields.description:
I wanted to follow a perfectly normal and feasible scenario: check out an old commit, to test for comparison.

 

Trying that resulted in a warning that scared the SHlT out of me:

"Checking out this commit will create a detached HEAD, and you will no longer be on any branch (unless you subsequently create a new one)."

 

I only dared to move on after searching the web about this action, and making an extra backup.

 

This is unnecessary and even WRONG.

The warning should tell what COULD happen, and how to avoid that.

 

It got even WORSE when I RETURNED to the previous head, without any changes.

"You are about to leave a detached HEAD and your current commit isn't reachable by others branches, which means they will not appear in the log after this action."

 

That sounds asif a disaster has ALREADY happened.

 

Please give more sensible and CORRECT warnings, without unnecessary SCARING people and WASTING their time.
fields.summary: Please make warning LESS SCARY about a detached head

fields.description:
I have been using Sourcetree 3.4.4.  We use custom actions extensively for many different uses.  When I would run custom action with the $FILE parameter that has a space in the file path or file name, the Sourecetree would automatically add quotes around the entire file path.  For example when I try to run lockfile.bat on 'testfile unit2.txt' it would run as 'lockfile.bat "testfile unit2.txt"'.  That way the entire filename is sent to the batch as one unit.

However when we updated to Sourcetree version 3.4.6 this has stopped.  Now it would run 'lockfile.bat testfile unit2.txt' and it would send two separate inputs 1)testfile and 2) unit2.txt

I am not sure what changed in between these versions but is that something that will be recovered in new versions?
fields.summary: Spaces in File path of Custom Action

Team Foundation Server 2015 supports pull requests through their web application and API. It would be a great addition to be able to create and complete these pull requests straight from SoucreTree. I believe TFS 2015 Update 2 has better API support as it's required by the Visual Studio Code extension for TFS.

With this in mind it would be awesome to have TFS added as an option when configuring the optional extended integration settings for your repository.

fields.description:
On windows, Sourcetree.exe will start "git.exe fsmonitor--daemon run" process for every local repository(even not opened in tab), I didn't found how to disable this feature, and what's worse, those process will keep running/existing after I close/shutdown the SourceTree.exe, and it'll prevent any action on my local repository folder, I have to kill them all one by one in task manager. It's strange, and kind of bug.

Additional info:
 * SourceTree version: 3.4.7
 * git version:   2.32.0.windows.2
 * OS: Window 10 Professional 1803 (17134.1304)

fields.description:
On Friday 12/10, a critical vulnerability tied to Apache log4j (CVE-2021-44228) was identified and a Red Alert was opened to identify and remediate this issue.  This vulnerability enables an attacker to download and execute malicious code with any string that is logged by log4j, so we must remediate this immediately.

Is SourceTree impacted?

If so: we need the following questions answered:

Is the vendor planning on providing an update to address this vulnerability? (Y/N):

What date is the vendor planning on releasing the update?:

If you had to open a support ticket with the vendor, what is the ticket number?:

 

Please respond to [erika.burrows@palmettogba.com|mailto:erika.burrows@palmettogba.com] or forward to the correct person to answer. Thank you!!
fields.summary: Log 4j vulnerability

fields.description:
According to [https://www.cvedetails.com/vulnerability-list/vendor_id-45/product_id-7281/Apache-Log4net.html] ST uses version 2.0.8.0 which is not robust, please upgrade log4net to version 2.0.10.0:

_"Apache log4net versions before 2.0.10 do not disable XML external entities when parsing log4net configuration files."_
fields.summary: SourceTree\app-3.4.7\log4net.dll

fields.description:
Whenever I use Sourcetree I get consistent graphics "glitches". When I mouse over menu items, icons, items in lists, etc. they either disappear or get replaced with blown up graphics. [Screenshot|[https://drive.google.com/file/d/1ywc1fNmLH2ko7chKfh0o_OoPL7YaZyWy/view?usp=sharing].]

 

This has happened sporadically for a couple of years now, but infrequently enough it has been no big deal. Recently I upgraded to Windows 11 and the problem is not constant, yielding Sourcetree nearly unusable.

fields.description:
I am using SourceTree on Windows.  I have SSH keys to validate the server connection.  So, when I start Sourcetree it launches the SSH Agent which then asks me for the passwords for each key. That is fine.

However, while I can see an option in SourceTree to "Add SSH Key" I cannot see how to remove one.  My actual problem is that, due to a misleading error message, I re-added the key and it now has the same key multiple times and asks for too many passwords at start-up!  But, more generally, I would like to be able to list and remove keys from the SSH agent.

I have tried using command line {{ssh-add}} but it says
{quote}Error connecting to agent: No such file or directory
{quote}
(Tried this both with windows CMD shell and in the Git bash terminal that SourceTree launches)

I see a running {{ssh-agent.exe}} process in Task Manager when SourceTree is running - in the Details tab. But in the Services tab it says the service is stopped. So, I guess SourceTree has started it but how do I connect to it? Alternatively, how to tell SourceTree not to start it's own but use the Windows Service?

I am using the OpenSSH SSH client (in SourceTree options).

If SourceTree is managing the SSH Agent (as it seems to be) and given it gives me the option to add a key, it should either include options to remove one or to launch some other UI (or even CLI) that can do so.
fields.summary: Cannot Remove Keys from SSH Agent

fields.description:
Sourcetree for Windows does not update the version string in the registry after auto-update. This is unfortunate when using package managers, such as winget, which rely on the registry to retrieve the current version.

 

On the screenshot you can see the version as reported by "Apps & Features" and on the right the version reported by Sourcetree.

!image-2021-11-28-17-47-17-086.png!
fields.summary: Versionstring not update after auto-update

fields.description:
The biggest issue isn't even the fact that SourceTree doesn't allow importing repositories without branches/commits but the fact that it crashes when it tries to. Instead, an error message should be displayed at least that the repository cannot be imported.

fields.description:
Hi,

I use SourceTree a lot in my day to day work. It would be extremely useful if it had a feature to pin favourite files, such as a .sln, .csproj etc file so that it can be launched directly from SourceTree.

I picture it being somewhere in the workspace menu; allowing me to use SourceTree to quickly access and open shortcuts to files in my projects.

User could pick the files to pin or automatically have certain File Types bought to the top of the list.

Double clicking a file would open it in the default editor, e.g. NotePad or Visual Studio.

A splash screen would list all pinned files in all tracked repositories, for easy navigation between each one.

!image-2021-11-02-16-45-44-835.png|width=504,height=247!

fields.description:
Generally, teams have one branch that's considered the main line of development (usually this is the "master" branch, or if using git-flow the "develop" branch). It would be helpful if that branch was visually distinctive in the log view's graph.

Today I had to inspect the history of several branches, and every time I checked out a branch our "develop" line changed color and moved around. This made it difficult to keep track of what happened after doing several operations.

I imagine two ways to do this, possibly done together:

1. Keep the "main" branch fixed as the left-most branch. If the branch at the top of the list isn't the main branch, then its graph starts in the "second" column. (mockup attached)

2. Choose a color for the main branch. If the main branch is set to blue, then no other branch will be colored blue.

Both of these imply that the user can choose, on a per-repository basis, which branch is considered the main one.
fields.summary: Visually and consistently distinguish the "main" branch

fields.description:
Hello,
I'm Roberto Martignano, an Atlassian Consultant from GetConnected, an Atlassian Platinum Partner based in Italy.
Our customer is having some problems with BitBucket and SourceTree.
When they close a branch with only one commit, this is integrated in the develop branch instead of creating a new one.
In a first moment a working workaround was to set "do not execute fast-forward" in the settings (see pic), but after a SourceTree update it is not working anymore, and a rebase is always executed.

I set "Affect/s Version" 3.4.4, but they are actually on *3.4.5* ([https://product-downloads.atlassian.com/software/sourcetree/windows/ga/ReleaseNotes_3.4.5.html)]

 

Do you have any idea of how we can fix this?

Thank you!
Roberto

fields.description:
Attempting to force push any branch will cause the push window to respawn indefinitely rather than trigger the push command.

{{push --force}} from CLI/terminal is not affected, so the terminal command can be used as a workaround for power users. Less technical users are unable to perform this action.

We observe the following error in logs:

fields.summary: Force push fails silently

fields.description:
I am working with ANSI-encoded files with contents containing German umlauts. After setting Sourcetree's default encoding to "Windows-1252", the diffs are shown correctly in the internal diff viewer. However, staging of hunks or lines that involve umlauts fails with the git error "patch does not apply".

Looking into %LOCALAPPDATA%\Atlassian\SourceTree\LastFailedPatch.txt I found that Sourcetree converts the diff from ANSI to UTF8 to generate the patch file (i.e. umlauts are shown correctly when viewing the patch file as UTF8-encoded). Git does not care about encoding, so it will try to apply the UTF8-encoded patch to the ANSI-encoded original file. This fails whenever the patch contains characters with representations that differ between ANSI and UTF8.

In my opinion the correct way to fix this bug would be to stop converting the patch content from whatever encoding it has to UTF8, because git will *not* convert it back to its original encoding before trying to apply it. As a quick test, I converted %LOCALAPPDATA%\Atlassian\SourceTree\LastFailedPatch.txt back to ANSI encoding and executed git apply manually, which then worked.

 

A similar issue for an older version of Sourcetree has been reported as SRCTREEWIN-8768.
fields.summary: Patch-based staging (hunk, line) fails for non-UTF8 encoded files

The summary is as follows.

The problem occurs when the local branch name is set as "unit_test/user/list/148-152,155,157,158,162,166-b,167,168".
When the above branch name is processed by SourceTree, it seems to be recognized as "unit_test/user/list/148-152".

 

When I run this in GUI, I get an error message "merge: origin/unit_test/user/list/148-152 - not something we can merge".
The symptoms are
{code:java}
$ git merge origin/unit_test/user/list/148-152{code}
The symptom is the same as when you run.

 

The result I'm hoping for is to run the following command
{code:java}
$ git merge origin/unit_test/user/list/148-152,155,157,158,162,166-b,167,168{code}
----
OS Name: Windows 10 Pro
OS Version: 2004

Git Version: 2.26.2.windows.1

Thank you.

The *Replace commit text?* dialog says

Replace commit text? [x]

Support multiple SSH keys

fields.description:
When using an SSH key with a passphrase, if SourceTree is open for a long time (e.g. all day), the SSH key is initially held open, but at some point appears to timeout.  After that, if you try to push, any hooks run, but the push just hangs until it eventually times out, but doesn't prompt for the SSH passphrase (or clearly state that's the problem).

To workaround, if the push appears to be taking too long, cancel the push, then open and close options, which re-prompts for the SSH passphrase, then re-push.
